Line 242: Line 242:
;Western world
;Western world
â
A joint statement by [[UK Prime Minister|Prime Minister]] [[David Cameron]], [[President of France|President]] [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] and [[Chancellor of Germany|Chancellor]] [[Angela Merkel]] of the UK, France and Germany, respectively, read: "...We recognise the moderating role President Mubarak has played over many years in the Middle East. We now urge him to show the same moderation in addressing the current situation in Egypt... It is essential that the further political, economic and social reforms President Mubarak has promised are implemented fully and quickly and meet the aspirations of the Egyptian people. The Egyptian people have legitimate grievances and a longing for a just and better future. We urge President Mubarak to embark on a process of transformation which should be reflected in a broad-based government and in free and fair elections."
+
A joint statement by [[UK Prime Minister|Prime Minister]] [[David Cameron]], [[President of France|President]] [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] and [[Chancellor of Germany|Chancellor]] [[Angela Merkel]] of the UK, France and Germany, respectively, read: "...We recognise the moderating role President Mubarak has played over many years in the Middle East. We now urge him to show the same moderation in addressing the current situation in Egypt... It is essential that the further political, economic and social reforms President Mubarak has promised are implemented fully and quickly and meet the aspirations of the Egyptian people. The Egyptian people have legitimate grievances and a longing for a just and better future. We urge President Mubarak to embark on a process of transformation which should be reflected in a broad-based government and in free and fair elections."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.number10.gov.uk/latest-news/2011/01/joint-uk-france-germany-statement-on-egypt-59740|title=Joint UK-France-Germany statement on Egypt|publisher=Number10.gov.uk|date=|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
â
<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.number10.gov.uk/latest-news/2011/01/joint-uk-france-germany-statement-on-egypt-59740|title=Joint UK-France-Germany statement on Egypt|publisher=Number10.gov.uk|date=|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
  â
[[Nick Clegg]] Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg compared the ongoing mass protests in Egypt to the fall of the Berlin Wall during his interview with BBC Breakfas...
 
After speaking to Mubarak, [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Barack Obama]] said that "the United States will continue to stand up for the rights of the Egyptian people and work with their government in pursuit of a future that is more just, more free, and more hopeful." He noted that in [[A New Beginning|2009 in Cairo]] he had stated "All governments must maintain power through consent, not coercion." He called upon the Egyptian government to restore its people's access to the internet and to "refrain from any violence against peaceful protestors."<ref name="Obama's statement">{{cite news|last=McCormack|first=John|title=Obama's Statement on Egypt|url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/blogs/obamas-statement-egypt_537615.html|accessdate=1 February 2011|work=[[The Weekly Standard]]|date=28 January 2011}}</ref> On 1 February, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that Obama has asked Mubarak not to run for another term in the elections later this year.<ref>{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{cite news|last=Landler|first=Mark|title=Obama Urges Mubarak Not To Run Again|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02transition.html?_r=2&hp|accessdate=1 February 2011|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=1 February 2011}}</ref>
After speaking to Mubarak, [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Barack Obama]] said that "the United States will continue to stand up for the rights of the Egyptian people and work with their government in pursuit of a future that is more just, more free, and more hopeful." He noted that in [[A New Beginning|2009 in Cairo]] he had stated "All governments must maintain power through consent, not coercion." He called upon the Egyptian government to restore its people's access to the internet and to "refrain from any violence against peaceful protestors."<ref name="Obama's statement">{{cite news|last=McCormack|first=John|title=Obama's Statement on Egypt|url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/blogs/obamas-statement-egypt_537615.html|accessdate=1 February 2011|work=[[The Weekly Standard]]|date=28 January 2011}}</ref> On 1 February, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that Obama has asked Mubarak not to run for another term in the elections later this year.<ref>{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{cite news|last=Landler|first=Mark|title=Obama Urges Mubarak Not To Run Again|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02transition.html?_r=2&hp|accessdate=1 February 2011|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=1 February 2011}}</ref>
